metadata.title: Selective conversion of furfuryl alcohol into butyl levulinate over zinc exchanged heteropoly tungstate supported on niobia catalysts

H2SO4 110 8 78 [30] H3PW12O40 110 2 58 [7] [MIMBS]PW12O40 110 12 88 [7] SBA-15-SO3H 110 4 96 [12] Zn1TPA/Nb2O5 110 5 94 Present work Selective conversion of furfuryl alcohol into butyl levulinate over zinc exchanged heteropoly tungstate supported on niobia catalysts B. Srinivasa Rao P. Krishna Kumari D. Dhanalakshmi N. Lingaiah ⁎ Catalysis Laboratory, Inorganic and Physical Chemistry Division, CSIR-Indian Institute of Chemical Technology, Hyderabad, 500 607, India Catalysis Laboratory Inorganic and Physical Chemistry Division CSIR-Indian Institute of Chemical Technology Hyderabad 500 607 India ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Selective synthesis of butyl levulinate by alcoholysis of furfuryl alcohol with n-butanol was achieved over of zinc exchanged tungstophosphoric acid supported on niobia catalysts. These catalysts were prepared and characterized by powder X-ray diffraction, FT-Infra red spectroscopy, pyridine adsorbed-FT-IR, temperature programmed desorption of ammonia, Laser Raman spectroscopy. The characterization results confirmed that the primary structure of Keggin ion of tungstophosphoric acid remained intact after exchange of its protons with zinc and subsequent dispersion on niobia. The exchange of Zn ions with the protons of heteropoly tungstate resulted in the creation of Lewis acidic sites. The catalysts were active for the synthesis of butyl levulinates under mild conditions within short reaction time. The activity of the catalysts related to the acidity of the catalysts which was dependent on the amount of Zn exchanged to the heteropoly tungstate on niobia. Reaction conditions were optimized and about 94% yield of n-butyl levulinate was achieved. The catalysts are reusable without any appreciable loss in activity. Keywords Furfuryl alcohol Alcoholysis Heteropoly acid Biomass Alkyl levulinates 1 Introduction The gradual decrease in fossil fuel resources and the impairment of environment led to look at alternative energy resources [1]. Cellulosic biomass is one of the abundant and renewable alternative energy resources [2,3]. Cellulose is the main source for the generation of sugars [4]. These sugars can be converted in to useful platform molecules such as 5-hydroxymethyl furfural, furfural and levulinic acid [5]. These platform chemicals can be further converted into commodity chemicals like furans, esters, polyols etc. Among the possible commodity chemicals alkyl levulinates are important chemicals due to their wide uses such as fuel additive, solvent, plasticizing and flavouring agents [6]. Alkyl levulinates are used in the synthesis of drug and chemical intermediates, since it contains both ketone and ester groups which makes them good building blocks [7]. Alkyl levulinates were identified in 2004 as one of the top ten biorefinery candidates. In particular, butyl levulinates is the food and drug administration of USA (FDA) approved flavour and fragrance. Butyl Levulinates were also used in solvent and plasticizer sectors [12]. Butyl levulinate is as one of the potential fuel additives with desirable characteristics among other alkyl levulinates. There are three different routes for the preparation of alkyl levulinates from carbohydrates as shown in Scheme 1 . The first route is the esterification of levulinic acid with alcohol in the presence of acid catalyst [8–11]. Secondly, furfuryl alcohol is also converted to alkyl levulinates by alcoholysis [12,13]. In addition to these two, there is a third route directly from carbohydrates [14,15]. Among these three routes preparation of alkyl levulinates from furfuryl alcohol is preferred due to its easy availability and high reactivity of alcoholysis reaction with desired selectivity compared to other methods. The alcoholysis of furfuryl alcohol was carried using homogenous and/or heterogeneous catalysts such as sulfonic acid-functionalized ionic liquids, sulfonic acid-functionalized carbon materials, zeolites, mixed-oxides, mesoporous alumino silicates, SO4 2−/ZrO2 and metal salts. Song and co-workers were investigated the production of alkyl levulinates from furfuryl alcohol in the presence of Bronsted acidic ionic liquids [16]. Chen et al. reported a series of sulfonic acid-functionalized carbon materials for dehydration of fructose to 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) and fructose alcoholises to alkyl levulinate [3]. Organo-inorganic hybrid solid acid catalysts were reported by Zhang et al. for the production of butyl levulinate with 93% yield from furfuryl alcohol. However, this catalyst was not reusable [7]. Valente and coworkers found that mesoporous alumino silicates (Al-TUD-1) were effective for the production of useful bio-based levulinate esters from HMF or furfuryl alcohol with aliphatic alcohols [17,18]. Recently Peng et al. used commercially available AlCl3 as a simple, cheap, and efficient catalyst for the synthesis of ethyl levulinate and the separation of the catalyst is difficult in this case [19]. Heteropolyacids (HPA) are well known as environmentally benign and economically feasible alternatives to traditional acid catalysts due to their Bronsted acidity, high proton mobility and relatively better stability. HPA exhibit excellent catalytic behaviour in a wide variety of acid-catalyzed reactions [20,21]. The disadvantages of heteropolyacids are due to their low specific surface area and high solubility in polar media. These demerits can be overcome by dispersing them on various porous materials and modifying them at their primary and secondary structure. Recently, the supported heteropolyacids have also been studied for the esterification of levulinic acid to produce alkyl levulinates [22]. Among the different possible acid and neutral supports to disperse HPA, niobia is well suited support. Niobia contains considerable amount of acidity which will be useful in obtaining highly acidic supported HPA catalysts. Extension of our interest in development of modified Keggin type heteropoly acid catalysts for various acid catalysed transformations, in the present work, a series of niobia supported zinc exchanged tungstophosphoric acid (TPA) catalysts were prepared and studied for the synthesis of butyl levulinate (BL) from furfuryl alcohol (FAL) and butanol. The variation in acidity with the presence of Zn ions in TPA and its dispersion on niobia was studied and correlated with the activity of furfuryl alcohol alcoholysis. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The chemicals Zn (NO3)2, TPA procured from Sigma- Aldrich Chemicals and Nb2O5 was obtained from CBMM-Brazil and used as received. The catalysts were prepared in two steps. In the first step Zn exchanged TPA was prepared by ion exchange method [23]. The calculated amount of TPA (Sigma Aldrich Chemicals dissolved in amount of distilled water and required quantity of aqueous Zn (NO3)2 solution was added drop wise with continuous stirring. The resulting mixture was aged for 1h at 80°C. The excess water was evaporated to dryness on a hot plate. The obtained catalyst mass was oven dried at 120°C for 12h and calcined at 300°C for 2h. The catalysts were designed as ZnxTPA where x=0.5, 1, 1.5. In the second step, the required quantity of ZnxTPA was dissolved in minimum amount of water and this solution was added drop wise to calculated amount of Nb2O5 with constant stirring. The excess water was removed by hot plate and the catalyst masses were dried in an oven at 120°C for 12h. Finally the catalysts were calcined at 300°C for 2h. These catalysts were denoted as ZnxTPA/Nb2O5. The content of ZnxTPA on niobia varied from 5 to 25wt%. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts FT-IR spectra of the catalysts were recorded on a DIGILAB (USA) IR spectrometer using the KBr disc method. The pyridine adsorption studies were carried out in the diffuse reflectance infra red Fourier transform (DRIFT) mode. In the typical experiment the catalyst was degassed under vacuum at 200°C for 3h followed by suspending dry pyridine. Then, the excess pyridine was removed by heating the sample at 120°C for1h. After cooling the sample to room temperature, FT-IR spectra of the pyridine-adsorbed samples were recorded. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the catalysts were recorded on a Rigaku Miniflex (Rigaku Corporation, Japan) X-ray diffractometer using Ni filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.5406Å) with a scan speed of 2° min−1 and a scan range of 10–80° at 30kV and 15mA. Temperature programmed desorption of ammonia (TPD) was carried on BELCAT-II (Belsorb, Japan). In a typical experiment about 0.05g of sample was pretreated at 300°C for 1h by passing helium (99.9%, 30mLmin−1). After pretreatment, the sample was saturated with anhydrous ammonia (10% NH3 balance He) at 100°C for 1h and subsequently flushed with He at the same temperature to remove physisorbed ammonia. Then the TPD analysis was carried out from ambient temperature to 800°C at a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 and the desorbed NH3 was measured using thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Confocal Micro-Raman spectra recorded at room temperature in the range of 200–1200cm−1 using Horiba Jobin-Yvon Lab Ram HR spectrometer with a 17mW internal He–Ne (Helium–Neon) laser source of excitation wavelength of 632.8nm. The catalyst samples in powder form (about 5–10mg) were usually loosely spread onto a glass slide below the confocal microscope for Raman measurements. 2.3 General reaction procedure All the reactions were performed in a 25mL round-bottom flask equipped with magnetic stir bar. The reactants FAL (0.098g, 1mmol), n-butanol (6mL) were taken in round-bottom flask and catalyst (0.3g) was added to the reaction mixture. Then, the reaction was carried at 110°C for 5h. The products were analysed by a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu 2010) equipped with a flame ionization detector using inno wax capillary column (diameter: 0.25mm, length: 30m). The products were also identified by GC–MS (Shimadzu, GCMS-QP2010S) analysis. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization The FT-IR spectra of Zn exchanged tungstophosphoric acid catalysts along with Zn1TPA and Nb2O5 are shown in Fig. 1 . Niobia showed two intense broad bands cantered around 695 and 990cm−1. Zn1TPA and all the Zn1TPA/Nb2O5 catalysts showed the characteristic bands of Keggin heteropoly tungstate at 1082, 988, 890cm−1. [24] These bands were related to asymmetric stretching vibrations of P-O, W=Ot and W-O-W of the primary Keggin structure. These results indicate that the Keggin structure was stable even after exchanging the protons of TPA with Zn2+ ions and its subsequent dispersion on niobia. The X-ray diffraction patterns of Zn1TPA, Nb2O5 and Zn1TPA supported on niobia catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . All the samples showed XRD peaks at 2Ɵ =22.6, 28.8, 36.5, 46.0, 50.5 and 54.9 which were related to orthorhombic TT-phase of Nb2O5 [25] and there were no characteristic peaks related to Keggin peaks of Zn1TPA. The absence of XRD peaks of Zn1TPA suggests that the active Zn1TPA component might be well dispersed on Nb2O5. Raman spectra of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 . All the catalysts showed a Raman band at 690cm−1, assigned to orthorhombic niobia [26]. As the Raman characteristic band related to Keggin Zn1TPA was not observed for the catalysts with 5 to 15wt% on niobia. However, the catalysts with 20 and 25wt% Zn1TPA on Nb2O5 showed a clear band at 1007cm−1 related to W=Ot symmetric stretching vibration of Keggin ion of Zn1TPA [27,28]. The acidity of the catalysts was measured by TPD of NH3 and the patterns are shown in Fig. 4 . The acidity values are calculated based on the amount of ammonia desorbed. The total acidity of the catalysts is shown in Table 1 . The patterns showed three desorption peaks in the range of 200–250, 400–500 and 500–600°C which were related to weak, moderate and strong acidic sites respectively. The support niobia showed less intense desorption peak related to low and moderate acidic sites. Bulk Zn1TPA showed less intense broad peak in the range of 200–300°C mostly related to Lewis acidic sites which might be generated due to the presence of Zn+2 ion in Keggin heteropoly tungstate It also showed a strong desorption peak at 530°C related to strong acidic sites. The catalysts with low Zn1TPA content (5–10%) showed broad desorption peak related to moderate acidic sites. The catalysts containing high content of Zn1TPA (15–25%) exhibited high temperature desorption peaks related to strong acidic sites. The desorption peaks in the range of 200–250°C were increased with increase in Zn1TPA content in the catalyst. These were might be related to Lewis acidic sites induced by the presence of Zn in heteropoly tungstate. Among the all catalysts loadings 20% Zn1TPA/Nb2O5 exhibited high amount of acidity. Pyridine adsorbed FT-IR spectroscopy can be used to investigate the presence of Bronsted and Lewis acidic sites in the catalyst. Pyridine adsorbed FT-IR spectra of Zn1TPA/Nb2O5 catalysts along with bulk Zn1TPA and niobia are shown in Fig. 5 . The spectra showed main bands in the region of 1400–1600cm−1 due to the stretching vibrations of M–N (metal–nitrogen) and NH (pyridinium ion). The catalysts showed bands at 1530 and 1630cm−1 are related to pyridine adsorbed on Bronsted acidic sites. Another intense band was located at 1485cm−1, which was a combined band originating from pyridine bonded to both Bronsted and Lewis acidic sites. The band related to Lewis acidic site was clearly seen at 1440 and 1580cm−1 for these catalysts and its intensity increased with increase in Zn1TPA content on niobia. The intensity of the band related to Bronsted acidic sites decreased with increase in Zn content indicating the generation of Lewis acidic sites in Zn1TPA/Nb2O5 catalysts. 3.2 Activity of Zn1TPA/Nb2O5 catalysts Initially the FAL alcoholysis was carried over Nb2O5 supported with different amounts of Zn exchanged with the protons of TPA (20%ZnxTPA/Nb2O5 where x=0.5, 1.0 and 1.5) catalysts. The Zn1TPA/Nb2O5 catalyst showed about 94% of BL formation compared to Zn0.5TPA/Nb2O5 and Zn1.5TPA/Nb2O5 catalysts which showed moderate yields of 56.8 and 75% respectively. The variation in the catalytic activity of ZnxTPA catalysts can be explained based on the acidic properties of the catalysts. The activity of ZnxTPA catalysts depended on the Zn2+ exchanged with the protons of TPA. Partial exchange of TPA protons with Zn2+ results in generation of Lewis acidic sites along with Bronsted acidic sites. The high activity is mainly related to the presence of Lewis acidic sites originated from the presence of Zn in Keggin structure of TPA. The partial exchanged catalyst Zn1TPA exhibited high activity as it contains more number of acidic sites. As the Zn1TPA/Nb2O5 catalyst showed high activity, the alcoholysis of FAL was studied over catalysts with different loadings of Zn1TPA on Nb2O5 and the results are shown in Fig. 6 . The activity of Nb2O5, TPA/Nb2O5 and Zn1TPA samples were also evaluated for the sake of comparison. A separate reaction was performed without catalyst and no conversion of FAL was observed. The support niobia showed moderate conversion of FAL and BL yield. Bulk Zn1TPA showed 100% FAL conversion with 92% selectivity to BL. However, this catalyst was partially soluble in the reaction mixture. The Zn1TPA catalyst was supported on niobia to make it as a heterogeneous catalyst. The TPA/Nb2O5 catalyst gave near 100% conversion of furfuryl alcohol with 42% and 18% of BL and butoxy methylfuran yield. All the Zn1TPA/Nb2O5 catalysts showed near 100% conversion of FAL. The yield of BL was increased with increase in Zn1TPA content on Nb2O5. The maximum BL yield was achieved with 20%Zn1TPA/Nb2O5 catalyst. Further increase in Zn1TPA content on Nb2O5 to 25%, the yield towards desired product was decreased. The activity of the catalysts can be explained based on their characteristics. The acidity of the catalysts increased with increase in Zn1TPA content on Nb2O5 and maximum acidity was observed for 20% Zn1TPA/Nb2O5 catalyst. The acidity and nature of acidic sites plays an important role in the preparation of butyl levulinates. Alcoholysis of FAL with ethanol reaction carried with different Lewis acidic aluminium salts like AlCl3, AlBr3, Al2(SO4)3, Al(NO3)3, Al(OTf)3 and Al(C6H5SO3)3 etc was reported. AlCl3 showed better ethyl levulinate (EL) yield compared to other salts which have more Bronsted acidity [19]. Mesoporous zirconia based mixed oxide catalysts with both moderate Bronsted and Lewis acidity showed relatively good ethyl levulinate yield [18]. When bulk TPA was used as catalyst, due to its strong Bronsted acidity alcoholysis reaction was preceded quickly with 100% FAL conversion with a low BL yield. It indicates that the strong Bronsted acidity may lead to the side reactions resulting low yield of BL [7]. Zhu and co-workers have reported only 48% of EL along with 40% of intermediate ethoxymethylfuran (EMF) using ZrO2 supported TPA catalyst in 6h at 120°C [29]. With all the results from previous reports, it can be observed that the catalyst with both optimum Lewis and Bronsted acidic sites were effective for FAL alcoholysis. The present catalytic system 20%Zn1TPA/Nb2O5 contains both Lewis and Bronsted acidic sites and exhibited better activity compared to other reported catalysts. The presence of Zn in TPA led to the generation of Lewis acidic sites as observed by pyridine adsorbed FT-IR. The presence of Lewis acidic sites, high acidity and well dispersed intact Keggin ion of Zn1TPA might be responsible for high yield of BL. The possible reaction mechanism is shown in Scheme 2 . In the first step, the hydroxyl group of furfuryl alcohol donates its loan pair of electrons to the Lewis acidic sites associated with Zn in the catalyst to yield oxonium ion. Afterwards the hydroxyl group might attracted by butanol to form butoxymethylfuran, which was identified as an intermediate by GC–MS analysis. In the third step butanol might attached to furan ring in the presence of catalyst to form 1, 4-addition product. Further butanol interacts with 1, 4-addition product to form 2-butoxy methylenefuran which is further protonated to form oxonium product. Then furan ring opening occurs with attach of water molecule to form dieneol intermediate, which would further transformed to butyl levulinates via the keto-enol isomerisation and the catalyst is regenerated [30]. H3PW12O40/Nb2O5 catalyst was synthesized and evaluated for alcoholysis reaction. This catalyst gave near 100% conversion of furfuryl alcohol with 42% of n-butyl levulinate yield and 18% of 2-butoxy methyl furan yield. During the reaction the reaction mixture became dark and this indicates that the furfuryl alcohol might polymerized to oligomeric condensation products. The catalyst without Zn gave low yield of desired butyl levulinates compared to the catalyst with Zn. These results indicate that the alcoholysis reaction is favoured by the combination of Bronsted/Lewis acidic sites of the catalyst. These results are in support of the proposed plausible reaction mechanism. 3.3 Effect of reaction temperature In order to determine the influence of reaction temperature on FAL alcoholysis to BL, the experiments were carried out at different reaction temperatures ranging from 70 to 130°C and the results are shown in Fig. 7 . When the reaction was performed at 70°C, the formation of BL was low. In general the alcoholysis of FAL with n-butanol undergoes via the formation of 2-butoxy methyl furan, which further converted into final product. In the present experiment, large amount of FAL was remained unchanged, indicating that the required intermediate formation was difficult at 70°C. When the reaction temperature was elevated to 90°C, the FAL conversion and BL yield were increased significantly. The yield of BL increased sharply, from 6 to 60% with increase in temperature from 70 to 90°C. Further increase in the temperature to 110°C, its influence was much more evident as FAL completely converted into BL. The temperature was further increased to 130°C, the yield of BL did not change considerably compared with that of 110°C. The results demonstrated that the optimum reaction temperature for the alcoholysis of FAL is 110°C. 3.4 Effect of reaction time Fig. 8 . shows the effect of reaction time on FAL alcoholysis at an optimum temperature of 110°C. FAL was completely converted with in 1h and about 46 and 54% of 2-butoxy methylfuran and BL were formed respectively. The formation of the desired BL was gradually increased with time up to 5h. As the reaction proceeded the yield of BL increased gradually at the same time a decrease in the amount of 2-butoxy methylfuran was observed. This indicates that the alcoholysis of FAL undergoes via the formation of 2-butoxy methylfuran as an intermediate which further converted to BL as the reaction progressed. These results support the proposed reaction mechanism over the present catalyst. 3.5 Effect of catalyst weight The influence of catalyst weight on the alcoholysis of FAL was conducted at 110°C for 5h by varying the catalyst weight from 0.05g to 0.3g and the results are shown in Fig. 9 . From figure it can be seen that the yield of BL increased with an increase in catalyst amount. The maximum yield of BL was achieved with 0.3g of catalyst. At the low amount of catalyst the conversion of FAL was moderate and the yield of BL was low. This is because of the formed intermediate was not fully converted to BL due to non availability of sufficient amount of catalytic active sites. A minimum amount of catalyst is need for the reaction to obtain BL. The increase in activity with increase in catalyst amount was due to the availability of more number of active sites. 3.6 Comparison with other solid acid catalysts The activity of Zn1TPA/Nb2O5 catalyst was compared with previously reported catalysts for the synthesis of BL from FAL and the comparison results are shown in Table 2 . The MIMBS ionic liquid exchanged TPA catalyst showed good BL yield at long reaction time of 12h and the pure TPA showed 58% of BL with in 2h of reaction time [7]. The sulphated SBA-15 catalyst exhibited maximum BL yield of 96% in 4h [12]. However, this catalysts reusability was not known. Generally sulphate ions are prone leach under the reaction conditions. The traditional organic acid H2SO4 gave 78% of BL with 8h of reaction time [31]. The present Zn1TPA/Nb2O5 catalyst showed maximum BL yield of 94% within 5h and the catalyst was reusable with consistent activity. 3.7 Catalyst reusability Reusability of the catalyst was an essential aspect of heterogeneous catalysts. Therefore, the recycling potential of Zn1TPA/Nb2O5 catalyst was studied for alcoholysis of FAL. After completion of the reaction, catalyst was separated by filtration, washed with ethyl acetate and dried at 120°C. The recovered catalyst was reused for next cycle. The results obtained by recycling the catalyst are shown in Fig. 10 . The catalytic activity was consistent even after fourth cycle. The retention of catalytic activity of the used catalyst might be due to the stability of Zn1TPA on Nb2O5. A leaching test was performed by carrying the reaction for 1h and then the catalyst was separated from reaction mixture. The reaction was further continued for 2 more hours without catalyst. There was no increase in the yield of BL. After completion of 3h of reaction, the separated catalyst was added to the reaction mixture again and continued for further 2h. The yield of BL increased. This indicates that there was no leaching of active component during the reaction. ICP-OES results also confirmed that there was no leaching of the catalyst. 4 Conclusions Niobia supported zinc exchanged tungstophosphoric acid catalysts were prepared with intact Keggin ion structure. Zn1TPA/Nb2O5 was an efficient catalyst for the preparation of BL from FAL with n-butanol. The activity of the catalysts depended on the amount of zinc exchanged with TPA which directs the overall acidity of the catalyst. Exchange of protons of TPA with Zn2+ resulted in generation of Lewis acidic sites. The yield of BL also depends on the reaction temperature, reaction time and amount of catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Selective synthesis of butyl levulinate by alcoholysis of furfuryl alcohol with n-butanol was achieved over of zinc exchanged tungstophosphoric acid supported on niobia catalysts. These catalysts were prepared and characterized by powder X-ray diffraction, FT-Infra red spectroscopy, pyridine adsorbed-FT-IR, temperature programmed desorption of ammonia, Laser Raman spectroscopy. The characterization results confirmed that the primary structure of Keggin ion of tungstophosphoric acid remained intact after exchange of its protons with zinc and subsequent dispersion on niobia. The exchange of Zn ions with the protons of heteropoly tungstate resulted in the creation of Lewis acidic sites. The catalysts were active for the synthesis of butyl levulinates under mild conditions within short reaction time. The activity of the catalysts related to the acidity of the catalysts which was dependent on the amount of Zn exchanged to the heteropoly tungstate on niobia. Reaction conditions were optimized and about 94% yield of n-butyl levulinate was achieved. The catalysts are reusable without any appreciable loss in activity.
coredata.dc:title: Selective conversion of furfuryl alcohol into butyl levulinate over zinc exchanged heteropoly tungstate supported on niobia catalysts
